Hillsboro High School Homecoming for 2020 has been scheduled for October 9-10, 2020. Your HHS Ex-Student Association Officers had a board meeting recently and would like your opinion regarding Homecoming festivities for this year. We are always open for suggestions on how to make the coffee and luncheon an even better event and welcome any and all volunteers.

Stay safe and stay well!

Many of our local students have researched Hillsboro history and will be putting on presentations in addition to representatives of different Hillsboro cultures and the premier of Main Street's "Cultures of Hillsboro" documentary.

She served as president of Fellowship of Christian Athletes. She was elected homecoming queen her senior year and was awarded the Eagle Excellence Award. This basketball, softball and track star intends to go into education where she wants to become a counselor. Congratulations Kassandra! We wish you all the best!

Please give from the heart each year to the Jack Neal Memorial Scholarship Fund and invest in the education of generations to come.

Inductees into the Hillsboro High School (HHS) Athletic Hall of Fame, which was formed last year, have been announced.
The 2015 inductees include the 1961 HHS football team, Douglas Conaway (HHS class of 1948), David Hawk, (HHS Class of 1951), Sally Spencer-Divin (HHS Class of 1997), and Michael Harris (HHS Class of 2001).
This year's Hall of Fame game is scheduled for Friday, September 25, at 7:30 p.m. at Eagle Field against the West Trojans.
The induction ceremony will begin at 10 a.m. Saturday, September 26, in the HHS gymnasium, located at 1600 Abbott Avenue. Admission will be free.
John (Doc) Robertson, head athletic trainer at the high school, is the HHS Athletic Hall of Fame liaison and said that sponsors are being sought to help ensure that the program is a success.
There are several levels of sponsorships available, starting at $10 for individuals and ending at $200.
For more information, call Robertson at the high school at 254.582.4100 or email robertson@hillsboroisd.org

Homecoming mums were first given in the early 1930's at high school homecoming football games across Texas and soon became part of Texas Football history. Boys offered real chrysanthemum flowers to their dates in the form of a corsage.

The simple look of the first mums have changed but the tradition continues. This week in Hillsboro every flower shop is working from opening until closing time to create unique mums to be worn during Homecoming this year.

These mums were photographed at It Can Be Arranged by Gary Evans at 115 East Franklin street. He shared that the new trend is that seniors wear silver mums! Most of the mums are still traditional but continue to get bigger each year and some mums now are made with several colors instead of the traditional school colors! That is so interesting to know but the sentiment is still the same: A mum signifies that Homecoming is a special time to be celebrated! "Mums" the word!
